description: {"blocks":[{"key":"f5fhv","text":"RNA-binding proteins are instrumental for post-transcriptional gene regulation, controlling all aspects throughout the lifecycle of RNA molecules. However, transcriptome-wide methods to profile RNA-protein interactions in vivo remain technically challenging and require large amounts of starting material. Herein, we present an improved library preparation strategy for crosslinking and immunoprecipitation (CLIP) that is based on tailing and ligation of cDNA molecules (TLC). TLC involves the generation of solid-phase cDNA, followed by ribotailing to increase the efficiency of subsequent adapter ligation. These modifications result in a streamlined, fully bead-based library preparation strategy, which eliminates time-consuming purification procedures and drastically reduces sample loss, allowing the profiling of RNA-protein interactions from as few as 1000 cells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":219,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5p71s","text":"In the accompanying manuscript, we have applied TLC-CLIP to four endogenous RNA-binding proteins, demonstrating its reproducibility and improved precision due to a higher number of crosslinking-induced deletions that serve as an intrinsic quality metric and increase both specificity and nucleotide-resolution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8cji7","text":"Demultiplexing and Trimming of Reads using Flexbar","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1r3j3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8901t","text":"This is done in a two-step approach for the following reason:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e34pr","text":"The easiest way to trim 3' adapter contamination is to specifcy the entire adapter sequence (see Flexbar_2 below) with 'N' being used for the i7 index positions so that this step does not have to be run individually for different i7 indeces.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"asqa9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"97lqs","text":"However, if this is specified together with --umi-tags, any bases on the 3' end that might correspond to the i7 index will be added to the read header and appended to the UMI which interferes with umi-tools as some UMIs will have more characters than others.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4j7fb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtccu","text":"As such it is easiest to handle the demultiplexing based on In-read barcodes as well as the UMIs in the first step, and then trim remaining homopolymers at the 5' end as well as adapter contamination at the 3' end in a second step. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
